awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Surgical training platform with customizable training scenarios enabled by 3D printing and artificial intelligence
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact /commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the development of a customizable surgical training platform supported by artificial intelligence.  Existing surgical simulators allow trainees to practice in safe environments prior to operating on patients. These simulators are limited in recreating the challenges of the operating room and providing feedback to assess trainees’ performance.  The technology developed in this project focuses on forming a better understanding of methods and techniques to recreate synthetic patient anatomy and how to provide higher quality assessments of surgical training procedures.  The project will provide a platform for improved medical training of medical students, residents and surgeons that results in better skilled medical practitioners that deliver higher quality patient outcomes.  

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project focuses on raising the quality of surgical training platforms by improving the realism of recreated anatomy and enabling scenario customization during training.  The project uses techniques of 3D printing, mechanical testing, and machine learning to characterize the properties of synthetic anatomy and objectively assess trainees’ surgical performance for each scenario.  The artificial intelligence will be trained by mechanical measurements of synthetic anatomy before/after training operations from users.  Comparisons of surgical performance will be conducted between experienced, practicing surgeons and inexperienced/less experienced medical students.  The anticipated results are the development of a customizable surgical platform that provides objective feedback on a personalized basis to improve the standards of surgical practice among trainees.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Surgery is challenging and important. A graduating medical student who wishes to become a surgeon must next complete a 5-year residency program. Surgery as a discipline remains rife with challenges in preparing medical students and residents for the complexity of surgery in the operating room, further compounded by new technologies and ever-growing global healthcare crises. In 2003, the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education (ACGME) adopted a set of regulations limiting resident work weeks to 80 hours. The surgeons of tomorrow face a more challenging set of occupational demands yet have the same educational window to become prepared.  Unfortunately, existing surgical simulators are limited in recreating the challenges of the operating room. Further, even top-tier medical education programs often only provide pig feet, bananas, and other objects for suture training due to the lack of effective commercial solutions. Simulators are typically very high cost and tend to focus on specialized niches, thereby limiting their adoption. Customer discovery has revealed that many surgical trainees are not sufficiently prepared for the operating room upon completion of residency and trial-by-fire experiential learning is relied upon to supplement the hands-on educational gap. This project proposed and pursued the development of a modular surgical training platform that enables users to train for diverse surgical scenarios to increase their confidence and competence, while also allowing purchasers to maximize return on investment for institutional training by producing better trained surgeons. To raise the quality of surgical training platforms by improving the realism of recreated anatomy and enabling scenario customization during training, the following key objectives were pursued with this project:

(1)   Develop realistic artificial tissues with a customizable process.

(2)   Analyze the forces, behavior, and failures of surgical closures.

(3)   Determine the necessary characteristics of an AI closure assessment tool.

R&D initiated with a review of the abdominal wall to inform design and manufacture of synthetic tissues with a customizable process. Each anatomical layer of the abdominal wall was categorized to understand the purpose and functionality of each layer pertaining to abdominal surgeries. A set of Key Mechanical Properties was produced through which Surgic engineers could classify these layers and develop analogs. Materials were selected and experimentally modified based on the likeness of their Key Mechanical Properties to that of real anatomy. The R&D for these materials resulted in a customizable library of artificial tissue analogs for the primary skin, fat, and fascia layers of the abdominal wall. Next, engineering testing standards and specifications were employed for mechanical testing of the customizable materials to map and validate their performance characteristics and enable comparison against human expert evaluation from surgeons as to how an artificial tissue should behave. The team leveraged 3D printing processes to enable rapid and cost-effective R&D for custom mold designs to produce easily manufacturable and modifiable test specimens. Additionally, an artificial abdominal wall was developed including all 8 primary layers: skin-epidermis, skin-dermis, subcutaneous fat, anterior fascia, abdominus muscles, linea alba, posterior fascia, and parietal peritoneum. A system to fasten and tension this abdominal wall analog - to mimic real human physiology - was developed which may form the basis for a future commercially available surgical training platform. R&D pushed into complex anatomical design using stereolithography (SLA) 3D printing technology and high-fidelity 3D organ models to create complex 3D printed molds of the major abdominal organs. The medical modeling aspects of this project explored the feasibility of translating a digital scan of a human structure relevant to abdominal surgery, adapting it in software and producing its mold; to create synthetic versions of complex abdominal anatomy for surgical education applications. Custom manufacturing setups were developed and, using the customizable materials above, artificial analogs of the major abdominal organs including the large intestine, stomach, spleen, liver, gall bladder, and kidney were created. Ultimately the utilization of materially and geometrically accurate complex anatomy including organs and vasculature will enable full procedure-specific surgical simulation scenarios/training models.

Advances in 3D-printing technology have enabled a higher complexity of anatomical modeling and design to produce realistic physical models and test specimens which are accurate to human form. This project has de-risked major aspects of the hardware, material, and manufacturing challenges to produce realistic surgical training platforms by understanding why surgical closures fail, what makes an artificial material realistic, and whether they are feasible to produce, beginning with midline abdominal surgery. Findings are described in the Final Report and may be summarized by the following statement:

The level of overall quality, as defined by its net utility as an education tool, of a surgical training platform may be understood as the degree to which the response of the system to human surgical intervention accurately mimics real surgery, such that an accurately simulated outcome may be used to improve surgical confidence and competence through realistic repetition, exposure, and feedback in a safe learning environment.


Last Modified: 11/19/2024
Modified by: Travis Reiss
